data.title: Newsweek
data.meta_description: Newsweek provides in-depth analysis, news and opinion about international issues, technology, business, culture and politics.
data.text:
Blinken urges Gaza ceasefire: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Monday the time is now to conclude a Gaza ceasefire agreement that would return hostages held by Hamas and bring relief to Palestinian suffering, according to the Associated Press.

Biden to deliver political swan song: President Joe Biden will make a speech tonight at the DNC where he will have to strike a delicate balance between touting his record in office and urging voters to back Vice President Kamala Harris. Here's what to expect. Read more about the DNC below.

North Korea condemns Ukraine's invasion: North Korea has denounced Ukrainian forces' advance into Russia's Kursk region, describing the "invasion" as part of a Western proxy war against Moscow, which invaded its neighbor in February 2022. Learn more.

DNC projects anti-Trump messages: Trump Tower in Chicago was lit up with anti-Trump messages last night, as the Democratic National Committee projected critiques onto the 92-story skyscraper — a day before the DNC kicked off in Chicago. See the dramatic images.

Hunter Biden tax fraud case: A judge who condemned an "abhorrent" protest against Jewish students at The University of California, Los Angeles, will oversee Hunter Biden's tax evasion case. Here's more details about Judge Mark Scarsi.

Chinese, Philippine vessels collide: Chinese and Philippine vessels collided on early Monday in the disputed South China Sea, according to officials from the two countries. Find out more.

In the ongoing war in Ukraine, Ukraine has advanced in several spots in Russia's Kursk region, a new map indicates, as Moscow wrestles with clamping down on Kyiv's incursion nearly two weeks after it was launched.

TL/DR: One of the most contentious policy areas for Democrats is Israel's war in Gaza.

The rundown: Democrats released their party platform on Sunday ahead of the Democratic National Convention kicking off today. Here's what it includes.

Why it matters: The detailed 92-page document outlines the party's policy priorities in several key areas. It was written before President Joe Biden dropped out of the race and Vice President Kamala Harris became the presumptive nominee, and so heavily features Biden's name and policies, even where they differ from policies Harris has since expressed support for. Meanwhile, Democrats plan to show support for Israel at DNC as pro-Palestine protests begin in Chicago.

Read more in-depth coverage:

DNC Update: Speakers and Schedule as Party Unites Behind Kamala Harris

What happens now? Democrats will vote on the platform this evening, and it is expected to pass as it is written. The convention runs through Thursday. Keynote speeches and programming begin at 6:30 p.m. ET today. The convention will run through Thursday.

TL/DR: In campaigning, Harris has repeatedly pledged to "take on" big corporations, echoing President Joe Biden's message of addressing inequality and high prices by requiring those entities to pay their "fair share."

The rundown: Vice President Kamala Harris has easily won over the well-educated progressives of the modern Democratic Party. The question is whether she can siphon enough non-college-educated voters from Donald Trump in swing states to win election as president. Find out here.

Why it matters: Politics in the 21st century has been defined by the Democratic Party's growing appeal amongst voters with college degrees while a Republican Party, once seen as representing the elite, has built support among working class voters who did not attend college. Of the 35 percent of Americans with a college degree, 61 percent voted for Biden in 2020, according to the Pew Research Center, while 53 percent of those without a college degree favored for Trump. Meanwhile, Senator Bernie Sanders has a plan for how Harris can win in November.

Read more in-depth coverage:

Kamala Harris Suffers Triple Polling Blow Before DNC Convention

What happens now? : Bernie Sanders stressed that issues such as climate change and abortion are also of vital importance but said, "in terms of politics," the wealth issue serves as a unifying force. Doug Sosnik, a senior advisor to former President Bill Clinton, agreed with Sanders that it was also essential for Harris to focus on working class concerns, but he noted that the battleground states of Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin are all toward the center of the list of most educated states.

TL/DR: The Israel National News reported that the person who died was a 50-year-old man who was pronounced dead at the scene on Lehi Street.

The rundown: A truck explosion that killed one person Sunday night in central Tel Aviv is being probed as a possible terrorist attack, according to multiple reports by Israeli media outlets.

Why it matters: The Times of Israel reported Sunday that Tel Aviv Police Commander Peretz Amar told reporters at the scene that the explosion was caused by a bomb that the man carried. The blast also injured a passerby, who might be able to assist in the investigation. The blast caused significant damage to a truck, but police assert that the man carried the explosive device. Sunday's explosion comes amid a pattern of escalating violence since the start of the ongoing Israel-Hamas war.

Read more in-depth coverage:

Israeli Airstrike Kills Two Hamas Militants Amid Rising Conflict

What happens now? The Israel Security Agency, along with police, is probing the incident. Against this backdrop of increasing hostilities, a new round of peace talks is scheduled to resume next week in Doha, Qatar. These negotiations aim to bring an end to the 10-month-long fighting in Gaza. However, the recent surge in violence casts uncertainty over the prospects for a peaceful resolution.

TL/DR: The destruction of the bridge near Zvannoye serves Zelensky's goal of impacting Russia's logistical capabilities.

The rundown: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Sunday spoke of his military's ongoing incursion into Russia's Kursk Oblast, saying his forces are working to create "a buffer zone on the territory." Here's what else he said.

Why it matters: His comments followed reports earlier in the day that Ukrainian forces had destroyed a second bridge in the Kursk region. The bridge's destruction over the Seym River near the village of Zvannoye comes just two days after Ukraine reportedly destroyed another bridge over the Seym in Kursk's Glushkovsky district. Earlier in the month, Ukraine launched its offensive operation in Kursk Oblast as war continues to rage between the two nations since Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered an invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

Read more in-depth coverage:

Kursk Bridge Destroyed in Precision HIMARS Strike

What happens now? The Ukrainian leader said that the "coming weeks will be crucial for our diplomatic efforts with various partners in Europe, America and the Global South."

TL/DR: After Hurricane Beryl left a trail of destruction stretching out as far as New England in early July, experts estimated damages and losses to have reached a total of up to $32 billion across the country.

The rundown: American homeowners living in vulnerable regions have long been used to coping with extreme weather events. However, climate change is changing the playing field for the home insurance sector in a way that they couldn't have prepared for. Here's what experts have to say.

Why it matters: Property insurance is disappearing from the most dangerous areas in the country; in others, premiums have become so expensive that some homeowners are willingly choosing to "go bare," quitting coverage altogether. The number of serious catastrophic disasters has gone up in recent years, as had the total damage from these events. This year, a total of $19 billion disaster events has already hit the country, according to National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Centers for Environmental Information. These include one tropical cyclone, 15 severe storms, one wildfire and two winter storms.

Read more in-depth coverage:

Florida Seniors 'Terrified' as Condo Crisis Could Leave Them Homeless

What happens now? Steve Bowen, chief science officer at Gallagher Re, believes that the sector can—and will have to—reform itself. "As technology improves and the quality of data becomes more granular, this should drive new innovation to better adapt and mitigate [risk] against the new climate reality in which we face today," he said.

Map Shows States Where People Live the Longest

Life expectancy rates in the U.S. vary significantly from state to state, reflecting a range of factors including healthcare access, lifestyle choices, and socioeconomic conditions.

According to recent data, the average life expectancy in the U.S. is approximately 77.5 years, but this average masks substantial differences at the state level.

Newsweek has mapped which states live the longest, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

The Full STORY
